resources.string: Channel with the fewest neighboring networks on this band. Device count: %1$d, average neighbor signal: %2$d dBm.
No channel information found for this band. You can try again using the \"Refresh\" button.
We need permission to analyze Wi-Fi channels.
To show nearby Wi-Fi networks and channels, Android requires apps to request a location-based permission. Without it, we can’t determine channel congestion.
This permission is used only for Wi-Fi scanning, and no location data is stored on your device.
If you previously denied the permission, you can change it from Settings > Apps > ChannelSense > Permissions.
This app scans nearby Wi-Fi networks and analyzes the channels they use. It suggests which channel you should choose to make your connection faster and more stable.
Because Android treats Wi-Fi scanning as location-related, we must request permission to perform this action.
This app does not store your location, send it to servers, or use it for advertising. All processing happens on your device.
The app does not change your router settings. Instead, it guides you to your router’s management screen and shows the steps you should follow.
An error occurred during Wi-Fi scanning.
Select your modem/router brand. Follow the steps below to change the channel setting to this channel.
The band that will be used by default when the Analyzer screen opens.
Automatically refresh Wi-Fi scanning at intervals. This setting applies while the Analyzer screen is open.
No channels to display for this band.
No valid gateway was found for the router interface. Please enter the IP address manually in your browser (e.g., 192.168.1.1).
Failed to open the router interface. Try entering the IP address manually in your browser: %1$s
Don’t forget to save the changes and, if necessary, restart your modem or Wi-Fi connection.
Open your router interface in a browser (usually 192.168.1.1 or 192.168.0.1).
Log in with your username and password. The default is often admin/admin, or the credentials provided by your ISP.
Go to the \"Wireless\" section in the menu.
If both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz are available, choose the band you want to change.
Find the \"Channel\" field and select channel %1$d.
Save the settings using the \"Save\" / \"Apply\" button.
Open your router interface in a browser (usually 192.168.1.1).
Enter your username and password on the login screen.
Open the \"Wireless\" section from the left menu.
Select the 2.4 GHz or 5 GHz band from the top tabs.
In the \"Control Channel\" section, change the channel to %1$d.
Open your router interface in a browser (usually 192.168.1.1 or 192.168.1.254).
Log in with your username and password.
Find the \"Wireless\" section in the interface.
Open the settings page for the band you want to change (2.4 GHz or 5 GHz).
Save the settings using the Save/Apply button.
Open the Keenetic interface in a browser (usually my.keenetic.net or 192.168.1.1).
Log in with your administrator account.
Go to Wi-Fi settings from a section like \"Home Network\".
Open the settings for the relevant network (2.4 GHz or 5 GHz).
Save the settings and restart the wireless connection if needed.
Open your router interface in a browser (usually 192.168.8.1 or 192.168.1.1).
Log in with your username and password.
Select the 2.4 GHz or 5 GHz band.
Open your modem/router management interface in a browser (usually 192.168.1.1 or 192.168.0.1).
Log in with your username and password. If you don’t know them, check the label on the device or your ISP documentation.
Open the settings screen for the 2.4 GHz or 5 GHz band.
Find the \"Channel\" field and select channel %1$d.
